SystemOutput2: The patient is a 55-year-old African American male who had his last visit on July 29th, 2008. He recently experienced new seizures, and his MRI results showed a right contrast temporal mass. The doctor is concerned that this could be a high-grade glioma and will need to conduct further tests.
Family history of stroke and sleep apnea.
No muscle or joint pain. No stiffness, weakness, or back pain.
Unremarkable.
Father died of thoracic aortic aneurysm, age 71. Mother died of stroke, age 81.
Reviewed and unchanged.

The patient is 77 years old and was sedated with Ativan due to shortness of breath upon arrival. She was unable to provide a history, and an X-ray was performed on her lungs. The report showed possible free air under her right diaphragm.

Parents and half-brothers have no health conditions. Maternal grandmother had DVT in her 40s. Aunt from father's side and cousins from mother's side have diabetes. Great grandfather had bone cancer in his 80s. Mother's brother diagnosed with leukemia at around 50 years old. Father's father had colon cancer from age 68 to 73.
Retired after working for 20 years in social security administration, enjoys traveling and being active with his wife. Social drinker, denies smoking or any drug use.
No known drug allergies.
The patient is a 79-year-old African American woman who is 5'3" tall and weighs 197 pounds. She has a history of type 2 diabetes since 1983 and no known allergies to medications.

The patient received the BCG vaccine in the Philippines before starting elementary school. He has been experiencing stomach uneasiness for a few days. There is no history of liver problems, gallbladder stones, fever, chills, or ulcers. His previous physical and blood tests were normal.
The patient lives alone but has a good support system from family and friends. They smoke but do not drink alcohol. They are aware of the risks of smoking and plan to quit eventually.

The patient has been feeling good lately and is managing their anxiety through therapy and an upcoming appointment with a psychiatrist. They also have a history of blood pressure issues, which are currently under control with medication.
The patient is doing well and has concerns about their liver due to frequent Tylenol use. They do not drink alcohol or smoke.
The patient denies experiencing headaches, breathlessness, skin problems, or chest pain. No other issues were reported.
PERIPHERAL VASCULAR: No cyanosis or pallor noted. No edema or swelling in fingers or toes.
The patient has no history of health issues or surgeries, except for their current concern.
Fatigue possibly due to multiple underlying conditions, including hypertension, high cholesterol, and osteoarthritis.

The patient is a 49-year-old white female who visited the dermatology office for a follow-up on her acne. She mentioned that her acne has improved but has been dealing with a rash on her chest, stomach, neck, and back for the past two months. The doctor identified small folliculitis lesions on her rash and attributed it to her acne flaring up. The patient has been taking 500 mg of Amoxicillin twice a day and using 0.1 Tazorac cream, which has helped improve her facial acne. She has also been getting photofacials at Healing Waters and is interested in exploring other cosmetic procedures or skincare products to maintain her appearance.

The patient is experiencing long-term swelling in their legs and numbness in their toes. They are unable to walk due to their weight and experience shortness of breath when attempting to move, as they have COPD. The patient is in constant pain and takes OxyContin for back pain relief. They do not experience any chest pain, visual problems, constipation, diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. However, they have sores on their legs that ooze.
Patient experiencing new chest pain described as a gnawing sensation, lasting a few seconds and rated 5-6 out of 10 in intensity. No shortness of breath or leg swelling reported.
The patient has been married for 45 years and lives in a waterfront house with his wife. He quit smoking in 1997 and occasionally enjoys a glass of wine or beer.
Sinus issues, history of stroke, non-smoker, non-drinker, no known allergies.
The patient is advised to follow a low salt diet and avoid foods with high levels of salt, such as chips, junk food, and pickles, due to their current condition.
Family history includes arthritis in the patient's grandmother and psoriasis in the patient's father.

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of ischemic cardiac disease. He had a stress test in February 2004, which showed some wall scarring but normal ejection fraction. He denies experiencing chest pain, palpitations, difficulty sleeping at night, leg or arm swelling, or shortness of breath while lying flat.
Positive for nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fever.
Discharged, patient went home.
Metastatic prostate cancer.
His father has arthritis in both hips.

The patient is a 55-year-old male who has been experiencing weakness in his right leg for about six months. He first noticed the issue when he was unable to stand on his right toe and has had difficulty pushing off when walking since then. He also experiences mild numbness and tingling in his toes. He has a history of back pain, which has been ongoing for many years, and cramping in both calves, which stopped about two months ago. The patient has not had any weakness in his left leg or pain around the area of numbness and tingling in his right leg. He has not experienced any bowel or bladder incontinence or radicular pain.  The patient saw another doctor in October before coming to see the current doctor. A CT scan showed degenerative changes but nothing obviously abnormal. The patient cannot have an MRI due to an ear implant. EMG and nerve conduction studies were performed. The patient has a history of elevated CK levels and has taken Lipitor for about 15 months, which initially increased his CK levels before they returned to their previous levels after stopping the medication. He recently started taking Zetia and has not experienced any weakness or pain since starting the medication.

Poison Control confirmed that the possible ingestion of the ant bait liquid is likely a small, nontoxic amount, and the child's behavior suggests she did not ingest any of it. The family is relieved and thankful for the information.
The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol.
The patient's sugar levels are well controlled. They have hepatitis C and HIV.
The patient is allergic to Bactrim, which causes nausea and vomiting, and adhesive tape, which causes skin rash.

The patient is a 56-year-old female who experienced a foot injury on November 26, 2007, at approximately 11:30 am. She does not recall the exact details of the incident but reports that her foot twisted and she experienced immediate pain. She has no other injuries at this time.
The patient has been smoking one pack per day for 15 years. They also have a history of alcohol and narcotic drug abuse, including oxycontin, and are seeking help for their addiction.

This is a 36-year-old white female who is experiencing significant left knee pain. She has had three Synvisc injections, with the last one being five days ago. The injections have provided about 35-40% improvement in her pain. She is still experiencing pinching pain when putting her full weight on the knee and has difficulty bending and straightening the knee. Her pain level is rated as 10/10. She has been using ice and heat, as well as taking Tylenol with codeine and ibuprofen for pain management, but these have provided minimal relief.
The patient confirmed no changes in medical and social history since the last visit. They are a non-smoker, non-drinker, and do not use drugs. They have no past surgeries or medical conditions.
The patient's recent C. diff colitis infection has been resolved, as confirmed by Dr. X. The patient also has hypertension and high cholesterol.
Patient presents with congestion and possible fever.

68-year-old patient presents with a bad cough and green-grey sputum production for the past three days. No shortness of breath, fever, or chills reported. Patient visited the ED due to concern about the sputum.
No intra-abdominal pathology noted.
The patient has a history of obesity, hypertension, a right knee fracture with pin surgery in 1990, and a history of blood clots.
Nasogastric tube for decompression, feeling better.

The patient has been suffering from congestion for a few years, possibly due to enlarged adenoids or their anatomy. They saw an ENT about a year ago but have no plans for a follow-up visit. The patient also has an ingrown toenail, which appears to be improving on its own.
Two-month-old baby girl with congestion for one week, fever for two days, and decreased milk intake. No difficulty breathing or wheezing reported. Diaper changes three to four times a day.
The patient is experiencing a headache due to stress from her husband and kids. She has never smoked before.

The patient is a 77-year-old white female who has a history of low back pain, lumbar scoliosis post laminectomy syndrome, lumbar spinal stenosis, and symptomatic right L2 radiculopathy. She underwent a laminectomy for spinal stenosis and has since experienced lower back pain and arthritis in her spine. She has been treated with injections into her lower back and right hip by Dr. XYZ. The most recent injection was in April 2005. X-rays taken today show marked degenerative changes and progression since her last x-rays in August 2004. The patient is still experiencing pain in her right hip, which worsens with weight-bearing activities. She has been using a cane for assistance and is considering a hip replacement but is unsure at this time. She is currently taking the generic for Ultracet, up to four times a day, but still experiences significant pain. The patient has an upcoming appointment with an orthopedist in Newton, closer to her home.

The patient is experiencing pain in his left wrist, which has been injured multiple times in the past. The most recent injury occurred while lifting items from the trunk of his car, causing increased pain near the pinky area of his wrist. The patient has a history of chronic scapholunate problems and other wrist issues. The doctor will look into possible treatments to alleviate the patient's wrist pain.
None.
No known medicine allergies.
The patient is a widower who lives alone and is retired. He does not smoke, drink, or use any illegal drugs. He considers himself very active, walking four miles daily.

The patient is following up for high blood pressure and high cholesterol. They have been checking their blood sugar regularly and recording the readings. The doctor reviewed the patient's blood work and noted that their cholesterol is still high, so they will continue taking the prescribed medication and monitoring their cholesterol intake. The patient will schedule another follow-up appointment after a blood draw in a few weeks. The patient's sinus symptoms have improved since starting the Z Pak.
Diarrhea for several weeks, occurring five to six times a day.
EYES: Negative for blurred vision, double vision, partial vision loss, or blind spots. No reported vision loss.

The patient reports feeling disoriented and confused on three occasions, with the most recent episode occurring while driving. The disorientation lasted about 10-15 minutes. The doctor recommends cognitive testing with a specialist.

The patient occasionally experiences an overactive bladder, especially during times of stress, but denies any pain with urination or other urinary symptoms. She also denies abdominal pain, excessive thirst or eating, constipation, diarrhea, heartburn, chest pain or tightness, shortness of breath, headaches, fever, and any problems with skin, muscles, or joints. The doctor plans to order an ultrasound of the patient's kidneys and run a urine test in the lab.
Mother and her two sisters have long-term asthma. No kidney problems or rheumatological disorders in the family.
EKG shows normal rhythm with leftward axis, no concerning findings. Blood tests show normal CBC and BMP, negative cardiac enzymes x1.
Amoxil and Aldex.
17-year-old patient with a 2mm fishbone obstructing her airway, requiring intubation and surgery.

This patient has high lipid levels, high blood pressure, and a possibility of metabolic syndrome. They tried following a meal plan provided by the doctor but felt they were still gaining weight. The patient has been engaging in physical activity, such as walking and gardening. They decided to try the South Beach Diet, which helped them lose some weight, but they recognize it may not be the healthiest option. The patient has come back to the doctor for recommendations on how to lose weight and implement a low-fat diet.

The patient has been experiencing shortness of breath for the past three days, which is a new symptom for them. They report that it gets worse with exertion. The patient denies any leg pain, swelling, chest pain, or history of asthma. The doctor recommends a CT scan of the chest to further investigate the issue. The patient's pulse ox is in the high nineties, so supplemental oxygen is not needed at this time.
Chemotherapy: Cycle 7 ifosphomide, mesna, and VP 16; patient feeling better.

The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, anemia, and IBS with bowel abnormalities. She reports her blood sugar and anemia have been stable recently, and her diarrhea has improved, likely due to resolving C. diff infection. She denies experiencing fever, chills, night sweats, unusual weight changes, visual or hearing changes, excessive thirst or frequent urination, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, urinary problems, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge, or any neurological symptoms such as blackouts, convulsions, seizures, paralysis, strokes, or headaches.

This 56-year-old right-handed male has a history of long-standing on and off lower back pain on the right side, which began after a motor vehicle accident in September 2005. The pain started five days after the accident and has gradually increased, radiating from the lower back to the buttocks, posterior thigh, and outside of the calf. The pain worsens when sitting for long periods or walking, but is relieved when lying down or standing. The patient has tried painkillers and a Medrol injection, which provided temporary relief but did not resolve the issue. There is no weakness or pain in the left leg, and no changes in bowel or urinary function. Upon examination, the patient's legs appear to have full strength and are symmetric, with normal straight leg raising.
Married, part-time farmer. Denied tobacco/ETOH/illicit drug use.
No history of surgery; all children born naturally.
Morphine, Darvocet, Flomax, Avodart, and Ibuprofen.
Patient appeared well-developed, well-nourished, and not in acute distress.
Noncontributory.

The patient is experiencing pain in the upper right side of their chest, along with occasional nausea and a reduced appetite. They deny having fever, diarrhea, headache, joint pain, seizures, loss of consciousness, or stroke-like symptoms. The patient's family does not have a history of similar chest pain.

This is a 68-year-old female who has been experiencing knee pain for 13 years. She previously had a knee replacement at another facility but is still experiencing significant pain, snapping, and difficulty walking due to her knee giving away. X-rays taken during the appointment show malalignment of the hardware from her previous surgery. The patient is seeking another surgery to address these issues.

The patient is an elderly male who has been doing well since his last visit. He reports no symptoms of heart disease or failure and has followed up with Doctor X. His blood sugar has been in a normal range, and he has not experienced any falls. He is experiencing some pain in his right knee, which he manages with Tylenol as needed. He is considering a knee brace for the pain. The patient's spirits are high, and he reports no issues with bathroom regularity or memory.
Normal male breast tissue, no concerns.
The patient has started a protein-rich diet, including whey protein and greens, and appears to be in good health.

The patient is bed-bound with a history of frequent UTIs but is currently not experiencing any urinary symptoms. They have been taking preventative measures and drinking more water. The patient denies fever, chills, weight changes, coughing, chest congestion, chest pain, shortness of breath, bleeding in feces or rectum, constipation, stomach pain, nausea, or vomiting.
Positive for prostate cancer, trouble holding urine, and left hip replacement surgery.
Patient not restrained, has palm protector in right hand.

The patient lives at home with his wife and is currently unemployed, having previously worked as an IT software developer. He smokes less than a pack of cigarettes a day but does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs.
Several relatives have high blood pressure and diabetes in the family.
Mild soreness in left arm due to vaccine, otherwise unremarkable ROS.

The patient reports feeling much better after taking Prednisone for a wasp sting, which was their first experience with such a sting. The redness and swelling have calmed down, and the patient hopes to avoid any future wasp stings.
No known surgeries.
No history of psychiatric disorders.

Mother and sister are present with the patient. They suspect she may have smoked or consumed weed in the past. The doctor also suspects drug use but cannot confirm which drug. They are encouraged to ask questions if needed.
GI: No issues reported. Cardiovascular: No heart issues. Genitourinary: No genital or urinary tract issues. Musculoskeletal: Normal range of motion, no muscle or movement issues.

The patient is currently on disability and lives with his girlfriend. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His activity level is minimal, and he requires assistance from his girlfriend for most daily activities. He cannot recall when he had his last drug test.

The patient has been skateboarding since they were 8 or 9 years old and occasionally goes to the skatepark with friends. They had a severe skateboarding accident two years ago but were not hospitalized.

75-year-old female patient presents with weakness, shakiness, and shortness of breath upon exertion. No chest pain, palpitations, cough, bloody sputum, wheezing, or fainting spells. Symptoms have been present for a while but have worsened recently.
Patient experiences migraine headaches occasionally, worsened by weather changes. Currently not seeing a neurologist, but doctor recommends a referral for a second opinion or brain scan.

The patient denies experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath. They report no bleeding disorders or prolonged bleeding. GI and urinary tract reports have already been provided, and the patient has no additional concerns.
Right intertrochanteric femur repair due to a fracture.

The patient is an 85-year-old who presented with muscle pain in the right buttocks region, which they believe may be radiating from their lower back or spine area. The patient has a history of high blood pressure, which has improved with their current medication. They have not experienced any side effects from the medication and deny any other issues such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, dizziness, lightheadedness, constipation, stomach pain, shortness of breath, chest pain, or difficulty breathing. The patient has tried Tylenol for the hip pain, which provided some relief. The doctor plans to prescribe a stronger medication for the pain and suggests taking it for a week. If the pain does not improve, they will consider taking x-rays.
No known drug allergies.
The patient drinks alcohol occasionally and attended a party over the weekend where she experienced back pain.

Personal history of hypertension and borderline elevated cholesterol levels. No personal history of heart disease or diabetes. No known family history of heart disease, diabetes, or hypertension. Plan to monitor cholesterol levels with a follow-up in one month.
No symptoms.

The patient is a 2-month-old female who has been experiencing congestion, coughing, and irregular breathing with retractions. She has had a fever ranging between 102 and 104 degrees. Her feeding has decreased, resulting in fewer wet diapers. The patient's sibling has an upper respiratory infection. The patient has been spitting up or vomiting after coughing and feedings, but has not experienced diarrhea.
Multivitamins and calcium.
Boil on buttock.

The patient is experiencing facial twitching and grimacing, along with a feeling of pressure in the back of their head that occurs approximately once a week. They describe the sensation as pins and needles and sometimes feel like water is running down their hair. The patient has been taking Aleve, which has provided some relief. Additionally, the patient is struggling with daydreaming at work and falling asleep in non-stimulating environments, such as in front of their desk or television. They work from 4 pm to midnight and have difficulty falling asleep after returning home, usually getting only 5-6 hours of sleep per night. The quality of their sleep is generally good, with only occasional waking up to use the bathroom. The patient is unsure if they snore and does not recall ever waking up to catch their breath.
The patient has had foot surgery, knee surgery, and a tummy surgery.
Reviewed and unchanged from the last visit.
No known drug allergies.

The patient is a 56-year-old white male presenting with a lump in his chest that has been present for at least a year. The lump is located on the left side of his chest and has grown in size, causing tenderness and pain when taking deep breaths.

The patient has been experiencing green nasal discharge and ear pain in both ears for about six days. The doctor suspects sinusitis and found fluid buildup in the right middle ear. The patient will be prescribed antibiotics and scheduled for a follow-up appointment to ensure the fluid in the ear has cleared.
No known allergies.

The patient is a 2.5-year-old girl with a history of seizures. She has been on Keppra solution 150mg twice a day, which has helped improve her seizures. However, recently her parents have noticed episodes where she stops and stares blankly for around 30-40 seconds, not responding to any stimuli. One instance occurred outside a store, where her skin around her mouth turned blue. No jerky motions were observed during these episodes. The patient's medication dosage has not been changed, and the doctor notes that the current dose seems low for her.
Grandfather was an alcoholic.
Anxiety medication and estrogen.
Sulfa allergy (dizziness and vomiting).
No other family members with heart problems.
Checkup and joint pain for a couple of weeks; Advil provides minimal relief.
Excedrin and ibuprofen for headaches, but they have not been helpful.
First pregnancy, excited for baby's arrival.
The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol.
Lives with boyfriend and three healthy children. Rarely drinks alcohol and denies tobacco or illicit drug use.

The patient is experiencing numbness and tingling in her right hand, primarily in the middle finger but also occasionally in the first and second fingers, as well as pain in her thumb. These symptoms have been ongoing for several weeks and are worse at night. She has tried adjusting her keyboard at work, as she spends most of her day typing on a computer. She is concerned about the possibility of carpal tunnel syndrome or arthritis. The doctor suggests further testing to confirm the cause of her symptoms.
Stopped taking Prevacid due to diarrhea.

The patient had a recent change of his urine bag, which is currently empty. A straight catheterization was performed, and the urine was sent to the lab. No leukocytes were seen, indicating no infection. However, there was blood during catheterization, but the urine is normal. The patient's X-ray showed stool in the colon. The patient appears to be fine and is very active.
Noncontributory. No alcohol or tobacco use.
Stable condition, unable to obtain history currently. Will page when awake and able to answer questions.

The patient is a woman diagnosed with Serotonin syndrome. Her symptoms included restlessness, agitation, and diarrhea, but she did not experience fever, tremor, or hyperreflexia. Her white blood cell count and CPK levels were high, but they improved after receiving IV fluids and discontinuing Prozac. The patient has a history of panic attacks, depression, and anxiety. A psychiatrist recommended Cymbalta as an alternative to Prozac, and the patient plans to see the psychiatrist and a counselor soon. She will be staying with a friend for the next three days and her daughter will visit her in two weeks. The patient is advised to continue her medications for high blood pressure and diabetes.

The patient is a 46-year-old female with a history of epilepsy and non-epileptic issues. She is concerned that she may be experiencing seizures again, as she has been waking up with strange body aches, confusion, and weakness. These symptoms also occur while she is at work, but she is often alone in her office. The doctor recommends a video EEG to gather more information on whether she is having epileptic seizures or non-epileptic events. The patient agrees to undergo the test today.
Nasogastric tube placed for decompression, patient feels better.

The patient is a follow-up for prostate cancer which has metastasized to the bladder and several locations throughout the body, including the spine and shoulder. The patient reports noticing blood in the urine again, starting yesterday and increasing today. The patient denies any changes in chronic lower back pain and denies any incontinence, fever, belly pain, nausea, or vomiting. The patient is able to pass urine normally and reports no blood in stools. The patient has completed chemotherapy and is currently undergoing radiation therapy targeted to the bones for pain relief and comfort. The patient has not yet looked into hospice care facilities but is interested in doing so. The focus of treatment at this point is on comfort and symptom management.

The patient has a history of hives, underwent dialysis for two years, and has high blood pressure. The doctor suspects that the patient's kidney problems may be associated with their high blood pressure and plans to investigate further.
Foreign body in left eye; possible need for eye doctor consultation.
High fever, possible febrile seizure.
The patient occasionally consumes alcohol (wine) but denies any history of tobacco or drug use.
The patient denies any history of drug abuse and has only consumed alcohol on special occasions. They have never smoked.
He is not on any blood thinners.

The patient is a 26-year-old African American male who experienced a pop in the back of his left leg after stepping off a hilo at work. He was placed in a splint and referred to ABC Orthopedics for further evaluation and treatment.

The patient is a young boy who has been having problems at school, including asking an unusual number of questions and being obsessed with cleaning and cleanliness. He does not relate well with classmates and has been experiencing confusion and depression. His unusual behaviors also include collecting old toys. He will be attending a social skills program during the summer and has been referred to two psychologists for functional behavioral analysis. He has stopped taking Zoloft and is currently on 7.5 mg of Abilify, which has improved the tremors in his hands.
Patient had a bypass surgery a few months ago and had a follow-up visit with the cardiologist last week. No family history of heart disease. Recent EKG results were normal.
None.

The patient is a one-year-old black female, originally from Tanzania, with a history of atopic eczema. She was referred to the dermatology office by the A B C Practice. The mother has been applying Elidel cream twice a day for six months, but it is no longer effective. The baby's skin is now dry, and the mother has been using Johnson's Baby oil. The baby appears to be well-developed and in good health for her age.
None known.

The patient is a healthcare worker who accidentally jammed a needle into his hand while working with a patient. The source patient tested negative for HIV but positive for Hepatitis C. The patient is coming in for regular screening and is scared about the potential consequences of the needlestick injury. The doctor reassures the patient that his Hepatitis B shots and Tetanus are up to date, and his liver function tests were normal. The patient does not have any local signs of infection, but does have some intestinal issues and vomiting. The doctor's examination shows that the patient's abdomen is fine, with no fever or swelling.
Feeling weak and shaky.
His two brothers and father have some type of cancer.
She lives with her husband, and her daughter and son-in-law live next door and check on them daily. Denied tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use.
The patient's family history includes a mother with metastatic breast cancer, a maternal aunt with bone cancer, and diabetes on both sides of the family, with adult onset diagnoses.

The patient is a 5-and-a-half-year-old male who initially broke both bones in his forearm in September 2007. He then re-broke the same bones about a month ago and underwent surgery with an ulnar nail placement. The nail is now prominently visible under the skin, and the doctor recommends removing it, even though it's early. After the nail removal, the patient will be placed in a cast for another three weeks and then re-evaluated. The risks of surgery, including infection, are very low, and the patient will be under anesthesia during the procedure. The family agrees to proceed with the surgery.
Aspirin, blood pressure medication, and diabetes medication.

The two-week-old newborn son is doing well overall. The family has a concern about his foreskin, but it appears to be not out of the ordinary upon examination. No other problems or issues have been reported.

Mother died of stroke in her late 50s, father had heart issues and high blood pressure. Patient was a heavy smoker (2-3 packs per day) but quit in 1990. Worked as a feed salesman for most of their adult life.

The 18-month-old Swedish American patient has had a fever for five days, with the temperature reaching 102.6°F for two days. The fever is higher at night. The patient recently finished Amoxil for a sinus infection and takes Zyrtec for allergies. The patient is teething, which may be causing fussiness and drooling. There is no diarrhea, vomiting, or coughing. The patient's nasal discharge is discolored in the morning but not during the day. The patient is eating well and appears hungry.
Significant for a back disc surgery approximately 7-8 years ago. No other surgeries reported.

The patient is experiencing FCR tendinitis and has been treated with cortisone shots in the past. She plays musical instruments, which occasionally worsen the pain. She has been managing the pain with anti-inflammatories and is seeking the doctor's opinion on whether surgery is necessary.
Father had diabetes.

The patient is experiencing chronic pain all over his body due to multiple past injuries, including being stabbed and shot. He has a history of heroin use and admits to using it again to cope with the pain. The patient struggles with cravings when the pain becomes severe.

The patient is a 47-year-old white female who presents with concerns about a possible spider bite on the back left side of her shoulder. She noticed the bump two days ago and reports that it is tender, red, and possibly getting bigger. She also has red streaks going up her neck. The patient denies having a fever but confirms that the area is slightly painful when touched.
No history of surgeries.
The patient lives with their family, which includes their parents and two younger sisters. They enjoy spending time together and have not been in contact with anyone who is sick.
X-ray results: Two views of the shoulder show no bone abnormalities or degenerative changes, indicating a normal and healthy shoulder.

This 51-year-old male presents to ABCD General Hospital with a history of degenerative joint disease in the MPJ of the big toe. The patient reports that the pain has been progressively getting worse and is now seeking surgical options to alleviate the pain.
The patient was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease by Dr. Johnson five years ago.
History of tonsillectomy due to recurrent infections.

The patient is a 57-year-old female who is concerned about wrinkles on her face and wants to look younger. She does not smoke and has no history of skin disease. Upon examination, the doctor notes that her submandibular and mid-face regions are predominantly full, and she has prominent nasolabial folds.

The patient is a 38-year-old female who presents with hip pain, primarily in her right hip but also recently starting in her left hip. She has been experiencing this pain for about two years, and it has been getting worse over time. The pain is located in the front and side of her hips, particularly in the groin area. She reports that walking is painful and she has started to hear popping and clicking sounds. This is her first time seeing a doctor for this issue.

The patient is a 53-year-old female with a herniated disc at T8-T9, causing rib pain. She has tried anti-inflammatory medications and rest, but has not found relief. She is inquiring about surgical options to alleviate her pain.
High blood pressure.

A 58-year-old female experienced sudden blindness, tongue numbness, and slurred speech on January 8, 1993. Her vision improved slightly before arriving at the local ER, but worsened shortly after. This was her first time experiencing these symptoms. While being evaluated, she became unresponsive and was not responding to deep noxious stimuli. She was then transferred to UIHC, where her symptoms improved markedly upon arrival.
Depression in a second cousin who had a nervous breakdown.

The patient is a female with a history of E. coli infections, having had episodes in November 2007, and May and July 2008. She was prescribed Macrobid for her most recent infection, but experienced complications such as skin rash and hives, leading her to discontinue the medication. Since stopping the medicine, her symptoms have improved, and she reports no pain with urination, blood in urine, fever, or chills. She urinates every 2-3 hours during the day and once at night, with good control over her urine. Her pelvic exercises and rehab have also helped improve her stress-related urinary issues. A renal ultrasound from August 5th, 2008 showed no hydronephrosis, masses, or stones.
Tylenol PM, water pill, blood thinner, multivitamins, folic, Norvasc, Lanoxin, Diovan, and Atenolol.

The patient is a 37-year-old left-handed male who visited the clinic one month ago for headaches, nausea, and vomiting. At that time, exams showed no evidence of bowel obstruction, and he was discharged home. However, his symptoms persisted, and he now experiences blurry vision, difficulty concentrating, and worsening headaches when sitting up. The headaches are dull, constant, and feel like a tight band around his head, starting from the forehead and moving to the back. They occur about six times a day and are relieved by lying down or putting his head between his knees. Along with the headaches, the patient experiences blurry eyesight, nausea, vomiting, light sensitivity, and sensitivity to loud sounds. He denies any blind spots, positive visual phenomena, weakness, numbness, tingling, double vision, or speech disorders. His weight has fluctuated over the past three months, and he has lost his appetite.

The patient is married and lives in a single-level home with her husband, who helps her with daily tasks. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks wine with dinner. She used to exercise daily but stopped in June 2008 due to back pain. She works full-time as a project manager, which requires her to walk for long periods throughout the day.

The patient enjoys traveling and has visited more than six countries. However, they have not traveled outside the country recently, with their last trip being a couple of years ago. They plan to travel again in the future.
The patient denies chest pain but reports shortness of breath after exertion. No bladder or bowel issues are present, and the patient denies any excessive or unstoppable bleeding issues.
Mother died from stomach cancer, sister had Alzheimer's and passed away from pneumonia complications, father died in a car accident, and brother died from mesothelioma due to asbestos exposure.
Allergic to Cephalexin.
The patient used to smoke cigarettes in the past but has since quit. The patient denies any current or past alcohol consumption.

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of stroke who presents today with urinary urgency and incontinence. She has tried VESIcare and is currently taking Enablex, but has not seen any improvement. She has not experienced blood in the urine, pain with urination, fever, or chills. The patient goes through several pairs of Depends a day. A urodynamics test from April 2008 showed significant detrusor instability with involuntary urinary incontinence and low bladder volumes, while the cystoscopy was unremarkable.
Asthma.

The patient is a 41-year-old white male with a history of HIV, high blood pressure, high triglyceride levels, and a recent diagnosis of diabetes. His last lab results in August 2007 showed a CD4 count of 425 and a viral load of less than 50. He was recently hospitalized for an abscess in his left glute and had surgery to remove and clean it out. He is currently taking Glucophage and glyburide for his diabetes, as he cannot afford insulin. The patient reports feeling better overall.
Negative past medical history.

Strong family history of Huntington disease, affecting the patient's mother, grandmother, and two younger brothers. Mother and grandmother both died from the disease. One brother is currently undergoing neurological treatment.
No known drug allergies.
No drug allergies.
The patient is married for ten years and does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs.

The patient's father died at age 84 from lung cancer and ischemic cardiac disease, while his mother died in her eighties from congestive heart failure. He has six sisters and two brothers, all of whom are in good health as far as he knows.

The patient is a 78-year-old woman with hypertension, which is managed with 25mg of hydrochlorothiazide and potassium chloride daily. She reports no chest pain, shortness of breath, dizzy spells, ankle swelling, or trouble breathing when sleeping. All intercranial lab work has come back negative.
The patient is a 66-year-old female who is experiencing dizziness. She has high blood pressure and an elevated heart rate. She may have a history of hypertension or tachycardia.

The patient is a female who had her last appointment three months ago. She has been experiencing variability in her glucose control and has had recent upper and lower respiratory illnesses, which improved on their own. She is still having difficulties with blood sugar management, with a two-week average of 191. The patient had issues with her infusion set, which may have contributed to her high blood sugar. After a correction bolus and consuming glucose and crackers, her blood sugar improved. She believes she can manage her blood sugar on her own. No other medical problems have interfered with her glucose control, but she has had some diet changes due to traveling and visiting family.
Currently taking Synthroid; stopped taking Aspirin, Terazosin, Lisinopril, and Atenolol.

HEENT exam: Eyes appear normal with no lesions, intact extraocular movements, normal sclerae, and pupils. No swelling, glaucoma, or cataracts observed. Ears appear normal with normal set and shape, normal hearing, and tympanic membrane. No hearing problems or tinnitus reported. No cough, cold, or sinus congestion. Oral exam normal. Patient recently had dental work done.

The patient stopped using drugs at age 25 and has been clean for over 10 years, with one relapse. He is still a heavy smoker and is aware of the health risks, especially with his chronic bronchitis, but finds it difficult to quit.

The child has been in good spirits with high energy levels but has experienced constipation issues lately. She has not gained any weight since her last visit, which may be due to her high energy level. The doctor advises focusing on increasing protein intake and maintaining a consistent meal schedule to help with weight gain.
The patient is married and lives with his wife. He does not smoke.
Divorced, homemaker, denies smoking and drinking.

The 72-year-old patient has a history of hypertension and was admitted in May 2009. She experienced abdominal pain, diarrhea, cramps, nausea, and vomiting in June 2009, which was suspected to be C Diff infection. A CT scan showed evidence of diffuse colitis, and she was treated with IV antibiotics (Flagyl and Levaquin) and IV Reglan for vomiting. Her white blood cell count remains high, but she no longer experiences nausea or vomiting. She still has diarrhea, which makes her feel weak, but reports no other symptoms.
Negative for throat discomfort, excess mucous, and soreness.

The patient is recovering well after surgery, experiencing some tenderness at the incision site but no new symptoms since June 10th, 2009. She has been following the doctor's instructions, remaining NPO, and is able to walk around without difficulty. The procedure went well and the patient should be able to resume eating soon.
None.
Flu shot received, no Pneumonia vaccination.
